releases.description:
The debut EP of Ronnie Makebelieve, a collaboration between kshack founders Mike Sheffield and Jeremy K.
Includes a liquid remix by Joey Anderson.

Reduction was recorded live in a single take in 2021. The duo of Salem Hilal and Jeremy Krinsley cut three segments and six tools out of the results and present them here alongside a remix by Lonefront.

"‘LoE3’ makes for an intriguing introduction to 504 Aquatic’s sound, nimbly stepping in the niche twixt spaced out rap instrumentals, footwork, electronica and dembow rhythms with their own finely calibrated physics.
Their title tune gets it off on the good foot with tight, puckered sub/kick drum patterns dancing in weightless space somewhere between AceMoma and Aught’s audities, and ‘Polycarbonate’ follows on a wicked slow/fast sort of paso doble dembow meter, left super spare and ripe for DJs to whisk it in-the-mix, with ‘Acrylic’ stripping back to dead crafty, bare bones bleep and bass permutations that sound like Dopplereffekt jamming with Topdown Dialectic.
JWords seals the deal with a sublime render of ‘LoE3’ suspended in buoyant ambient rap headspace.
One to keep an eye on."
- Boomkat

"Vermilion" is the latest installment from New York City-based artist Isn’t Ours. The six-track EP includes five disciplined explorations of electro, bass, IDM, and gabber, as well as a sea-change remix courtesy of Moscow-based artists buttechno and Triš.
An exploration into the primordial and heretical motivations behind creating art, "Vermilion" features analogue and digital elements, guitar feedback, found sound, and is indebted to works by Carl Jung, William Blake, Heinrich Khunrath, Editions Mego, and Playboi Carti.
It was recorded in a windowless basement room in Bed-Stuy, with additional mixing provided by Joe Plourde and mastering by Stephan Mathieu.

"Glyphs for Second System" is the first release by 89.SYM. It consists of on-grid dance tracks with the drums ripped out, field recordings and single takes, cut-up samples, drones, and autonomic melodies pulled from nostalgic harmonic memories and dreams about extraterrestrials.
Recorded and produced in different contexts over the past year, “Glyphs for Second System” is drum-less music centered on keyboard improvisation and a devotion to studio chance.

"I will grow different, separate from all that is dear and appealing to me” is the first release from American ambient and shoegaze artist clairaudience. Distorted, blended, and bent guitar rips through a wall of tape feedback, evoking thoughts of nostalgia and annihilation. The title takes its name from “Upajjhatthana Sutta: Subjects for Contemplation,” the Buddhist discourse famous for its inclusion of five remembrances – five facts regarding life’s fragility and our true inheritance.
This project was born out of a place of grief and chance. Upon learning that a close friend had passed, the artist was searching through an old hard drive for pictures and remembrances when he found a folder named “clairaudience” from 10 years earlier. While the material from “I will grow different...” is not that exact music, the music that was found was a related body of work which already had a name and finite point of view and would go on to inform this release.

"Bite" is Salem Hilal's first solo release with kshack. It features three studies in rhythm and club-forward drum programming, as well as "Ambient Meditation 1", an exercise on stretching a simple melody over a long arc.
Hilal records live hardware performances and strips them down to hard-hitting techno and expansive ambient explorations.
He has released music on Cultivated Sound and Blank Stairs. His most recent release was on kshack with the techno duo Sleep 300.
'Divine -C' is the second release by 504 Aquatic. It features five crisp and tangy dance tracks, and two palette-cleansing remixes by Sweater on Polo and Isn't Ours.

'Let' is the first EP by Mike Crowley. It features four original tracks and a remix by Guilt Attendant.
The EP emerged from Crowley's interest in somatics, or the study of dance through autonomic, body-centric movement. Producing the tracks involved the same process of stepping away from self and letting sounds be.
The album art is from Nikolai Bernstein's socialist research into industrial movement during production processes, which was generated with an early time-lapse technique that used tiny strobelights.
Additional mixing by Maxime Robillard

'Denature' is the second full-length album from techno duo Sleep 300. All tracks were recorded live with no further post-production. The release closes with two remixes, one by each of Sleep 300's life-long contributing members.

Astronomers and amateurs interested in observing deep-sky objects know: 'NGC' is the New General Catalogue. For production duo Ronnie Makebelieve, NGC signifies a new direction for their second public release. This collection includes elements of leftfield techno, bass, acid house music, and a damaging DnB workout remix by Dwarde.
Ronnie Makebelieve is the production duo of Mike Sheffield and Jeremy Krinsley, New York City artists who have released music under various monikers for imprints including Godmode, Dull Tools, and Fire Talk. They founded the kshack imprint together in early 2021.
Remixer Dinn Warde, aka Dwarde, is an electronic music artist and jungle producer from Darlington, England. He has released music on 7th Storey Projects, Future Retro London, Beyond Electronix, Distant Planet, and as part of the Simpsons-themed project Globex Corp alongside longtime collaborator Tim Reaper.

Turn on, tune in, dub out.
Lightcyan is the latest moniker from Queens-based artist and producer Mike Sheffield. For this new moniker, Sheffield begins with a set of two original EPs, M and 484, which pay homage to downtempo and liquid DnB moods, respectively. First, "the come up," due for an August 25th release date, is M.
M starts with “Deer Park,” an introspective, chugging, ambient house classic. It’s catnip for slow dubbed out DJ sets, with string hits reminiscent of Tangerine Dream. “In Dreams’ Projections” is another DJ tool for those looking to guide a mid tempo journey into psychedelia. The third track, “Anima/Animus” diverges from the more balearic feel of the first two, with an explosive sub bass line hinting at the DnB to come on the next EP. The title track “M,” veers into psybient via dub, conjuring a dissociative state that hovers somewhere between nostalgic trip hop and the unknown. It provides the perfect bedrock for a punishing bass rework via fellow kshack artist 504 Aquatic.

TEXTURAL BIAS plays with contrasting sonic characteristics. While the five tracks on the release are distinct explorations, the doctor meticulously sculpts them into a single coherent musical statement that smoothly carves space for remixes by RAMZi and Ronnie Makebelieve. The EP is dr. button’s first officially distributed release.
dr. buttons is Joe Plourde. Plourde is a composer, producer, audio engineer, and sound designer who spent years working in music studios and touring in rock bands before transitioning to electronic music production and sound designing professional podcasts (for which he has won a DuPont and been nominated for a Peabody). He loves spending time in the kitchen and trying new things.

Chronic Fatigue’s self-titled debut synthesizes poetry and machine music. The duo employ a minimalist approach, fabricating a rich aural tapestry with vocals and a single Korg Volca Beats.
The EP features a techno remix of “Paranoia” reconstructed by MAL.E (a.k.a. Sweater on Polo) reminiscent of early Robert Hood compositions from his Detroit imprint M-plant.
Purchase of the EP includes a lyrics booklet designed by Chronic Fatigue.

'484' is the second Lightcyan EP by Queens-based artist and producer Mike Sheffield.
Named after the iconic Polaris supercar, the EP begins with 'Near/After', a shoegaze-drenched liquid DnB anthem with a sneaky bass line that is sure to rattle any club system. Title track “484” sees Lightcyan’s most accessible track yet, with a warped R&B vocal hook and a shifting synth line that recedes and reappears before you can be sure of exactly what you have just heard. 'Catamaran' and 'Memory’s Heat' bring about a wave of leftfield house, while the EP rounds out with 'Secret Road', a jungle hot rod that conjures images of arcade halls and high speed racing video games of yore. The EP closes with a special remix of 'Near/After' by kshack labelmate dr. buttons.

Welcome to Greem Jellyfish's latest EP, which answers the eternal question: What is soap?
The release includes remixes by Costin Rp, EscaFlowne, Lightcyan, and 504 Aquatic, as well as original artwork by Greem Jellyfish.
Greem Jellyfish is a visual artist, DJ, and composer raised in Seoul and based in New York. Her work explores the boundaries between play, sensuality, paradox, and bubbles.

'celebrations' is a dub/ambient collaboration between the right and left neocortices of kshack co-founder Jeremy K. They released the first album by 89.SYM in 2022 to a bit of love ('mesmerising', said Boomkat). They pass the project like a party joint to synbi93, a new home for these autonomic abstractions and personal explorations.

For their third release, Sleep 300 detours from live recordings into carefully woven techno. 'Julienne' opens with a spoken sci-fi dj tool and follows the thread through three peak-hour studies in dance maximalism, tying it up with a warbled ambient outro, as a little treat.

'Entropy Lock' is the newest EP by 504 Aquatic. It was inspired by the sound of ice crystals cracking, the sensation of bass, and getting stuck in time warps.
504 Aquatic has released three EPs of slanted bass music blessed with remixes by Plebeian, JWords, and Sweater on Polo.

Negative Supply are an early 2000s hardware techno duo with a trail of blown out cassette-only releases. Their first EP in fifteen years opens with a meditation, centers a tasty 504 Aquatic collab, and paves the exit with a wall of techno.

Recovered from a damaged hard drive in the fall of 2024, the original Crystal Vision 'found mix' was composed fifteen years ago for a wedding. 'Crystal Vision Love Potion' features the original tune alongside three fresh interpretations. The results are jungly and deep and primed for your local club or seance.

"Besides the world which we can describe, there is another kind of world."
All songs composed by Mike Sheffield
Recorded between 2022 and 2025 in Queens, NY
Mixed by Mike Sheffield and Jeremy Krinsley in Brooklyn, NY
Mastered by Stephan Mathieu in Bonn, Germany
Vocals by Jess Paps on “sudden awareness of an absence,” “grief guitar,” “the act of seeing with one’s own eyes,” “ocean of light,” and “devotions of ecstasy”
Additional vocals by Lani Combier-Kapel on “sudden awareness of an absence,” “the act of seeing with one’s own eyes,” “ocean of light,” and “devotions of ecstasy”
Additional electronics by Kiran Arora on “letters from the world of emptiness,” recorded in Barcelona, Spain
Cover photo by Mike Sheffield

Have you been experiencing a faint but persistent vibration emanating from that star cluster nestled high above New York’s midnight sky? You might be feeling the Summer Triangle. Introducing D. Daiz on the EP’s last track, ‘Swan’.
